text: Patient: No. Today I did. Doctor: So that was your first one ever? Patient: Uh-huh. Doctor: Okay. Okay. So because of your PSA going up, we checked scans. The bone scan tells us that, huh, you’ve got a lot of cancer in your bones. We sort of knew that from before even though we haven’t had a picture of that, and so, again, when they talk about what this looks like I have nothing to compare it to. Huh, but this is you, your body, these things here represent the cancer. So here’s your back bone, also a lot of it here in your ribs in multiple spots, a couple of areas on the skull bone that look like there’s cancer there, or one area in this, huh, your right, your left leg. Huh, huh, and then the CAT scan says, huh, that’s what we had used at the very beginning, huh, which says that basically all the areas in the bone that they saw before are still there, huh, with, huh, additional spots. Huh, and you’ve got some really small lymph nodes down in your pelvis. All that is doctor lingo for, huh, you know, you’ve had benefit from the hormone therapy, huh, but I really can’t tell you how much worse it is because these are the first real pictures since you’ve gotten started. You’re hanging in there, huh, but it would be, you know, time to change therapy. Family Member: Okay. We know. Patient: So what kind of pills can I take? Doctor: Huh, so the most common pill would be a drug called abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, if you’ll excuse me one second, I’ll ask one colleague a question. I’ll be right with you. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: The enzalutamide, what you were saying- Family Member: Let him, let him, let him ask a colleague a question. He’ll be right back. Patient: I mean I’m just- Doctor: Okay. You remember it?

text: Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So there there isn’t a but you’re not getting any therapy or you’re getting only a pla-placebo potentially. So, in response to what you just said which is you you wanna get some drug back into your system- Patient: Yup. Doctor: That the clinical trial will give you the option of doing that um potentially with something experimental out and on- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But not necessarily. Um just a couple of words about the side effects and they’re all listed in this consent form which is fourteen pages long, so it’s quite detailed. But um the main side effects are listed in section four and I will read that with you so you can look at it. We have seen some fatigue with this medication. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We have seen some nausea in some people. We have some seen some rash, you know a few people ten to fifteen percent. Um we are going to keep a very close eye on your liver function and kidney function to make sure that those weren’t affected by the drug. Uh some people have a uh worsening of their hot flashes, because of the Xtandi itself cause worsening of the hot flashes. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um some people can have a uh decreased energy or they might feel more tired. Um but I, I would have to say in general these side effects are all better than what we see in chemotherapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: So it it it does seem to be the best

text: Family Member: So, like every other week or something like that? Doctor: Yes. Yeah. Every two weeks we will need him here the whole day or at least half the day because we have to make sure your, uh blood counts are okay, everything is okay, and then we give you the IV medicine, and, you know, either way- Patient: Radiation? Doctor: Yes, both the radiation, the radiation is once a month, but the IV immune therapy is once every two weeks. Okay? Family Member: So the thing is, Dr. V___, - Doctor: Um, hum. text: Patient: Yesterday for some reason all in my back was pain from my shoulder blades, to my shoulders all through my back. And I took a uh Nap-nabarone. Doctor: N-naprosyn. Patient: Yeah I took and sleep Doctor: Okay. And did you take one today as well? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. So it didn’t come back today? Patient: No. Doctor: Um hum. Have you been losing or gaining any weight? Patient: Uh, I guess I been Doctor: And do you think that’s because your appetite has dropped or you’re losing even if you’re eating the same amount. Patient: Somewhat the same amount. Doctor: Okay. And can you remind me who lives with you at home? Are you on your own or do you have other family members with you?

text: Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: What I would like to do, is uh I would like to leave you with this information. Please don’t read it now because I want you to take your time with it. Um it’s it’s pretty intense reading but if if you take it slowly, and then maybe you have people in your family with you, going over it with you. Um and then in in about a week um we will call you back up. I will have my research nurse reach out to you by telephone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And uh see what you think. By then we will have the information from the PSA. And if the PSA is rising again, it it would be my recommendation that at the very least we start the Xtandi. And then addition to that, possibly to consider the clinical trial. But at the very least, I do think Xtandi is going to be a part of your treatment. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And if the PSA has somehow stabilized or dropped on its own, which I don’t anticipate in this case- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But if it has dropped on its own, then I will rewrite your prescription and reauthorize your prescription for the Abiraterone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, having said all that, I do anticipate that we’re going to be switching gears. Patient: Okay. Sound good to me. Doctor: Are there any other questions you have for me about the clinical trial or about the Xtandi itself?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s a question of taking two pills versus one pill. Okay. There’s a forty percent chance that the coin will flip coin will flip in that direction and you will be selected to take only the Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And there’s a sixty percent chance that the coin will flip and you will get selected to receive the combination, the FDA approved drug plus the experimental drug. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: This is not a drug that even if I really wanted you to get on this group, I could just prescribe. Because not been FDA approved for any cancer type, um certainly not for prostate cancer. Um, but the thing that I always want people to understand, when it comes to this clinical trial is, that if you decide you you want to participate in it, you need to conscious of both scenarios. In other words, if you know in your heart of heart-heart’s that you’re going to drop out if you don’t need the new drug (beeper sounds) Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Then please let me know and we will not do this with you, just give you the routine treatment. Okay. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So, I just wanted to s-stop there at the moment and I want to give you this piece of paper so you can look at it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and do you have any questions about any of that because I know it can be quite complicated and uh information. Doctor: Exactly. The the good thing about this trial I did not mention, I think I should, um there’s no placebo involved. So there are some studies where they give people um a sugar pill or basically inactive medication. This trial does not involve a placebo. And also in this trial, in both groups, both of you get the Xtandi by itself or the Xtandi plus the new experimental drug active therapy.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So how are things going since the last time I saw you a couple months ago? Patient: I’m feelin’ fine. Well, let’s put it this way… Energy, lack of energy. That’s my number one complaint. Doctor: Okay. Is that getting any better, any worse or staying the same? Patient: I - It appears to be getting worse. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t know, I…maybe it’s age. Doctor: You’re not that old yet. (laughs) Patient: Oh. (chuckles) Doctor: That’s young, in this day and age. Patient: Yeah. Uh-huh. Doctor: Any other new symptoms? So fatigue is maybe a bit worse? Patient: I feel so; I, I uh I govern that by my ability to you know do things around the house. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
